while i was at church yesterday, i had what might become a v. important realisation. i was looking at people who i remember as young people in the church who are now married and coming with their children, and i thought "i don't want that to be me!" i don't want to be the parent who takes their child to the open day at their old school and remembers all the teachers. i don't want to be going to church in my late 20s/early 30s and still have people refusing to belive that i've grown up and still thinking that i'm 16. i don't want to live in carrick for the rest of my life! the only problem now is that while i know what i don't want, i'm not really sure what i do want! i'm just praying now that the year in new zealand will be a time when i can really discover what God's plan for me is. i think i've been avoiding seeking God's will for the past couple of years because i've been scared to move on. it's easier to drift into things and stay there for lack of anything better than to actively seek something different. but i think it's time for a change...

i have never been the master of the well-chosen phrase. i often feel i should carry a thesaurus around with me to help me pinpoint the words that regularly escape my grasp. (in fact, some of my friends are pretty good substitutes, able to fill in my "whatevers" and "thingumajigs" with ease.) i think instead, my gift lies in absorbing other people's words. my memory seems to have an almost boundless capacity for retaining books i have read, films i've seen, songs i've heard and sung, snatches of poems...sometimes i swim in a sea of words not my own, able to see and touch but not able to turn them to my own ends. which is really a long-winded way of saying "this is why i do not blog very often".

i feel i may be a hoarder. this is a realisation i have been trying to avoid for the past few months, but sadly i can no longer hide the truth. perhaps i should have felt this encroaching when i discovered that i had birthday cards from my grampy who died in 1994. but i figured, "well, i kept them for sentimental reasons, so it doesn't really count". or the fact that a box of cards/photos/bits and bobs that were the main decoration of my room in my third year of uni lie undisturbed in the top of my wardrobe. no, it seems that, to quote an old cliche, denial ain't just a river in egypt. i am a hoarder, and it was finding all my travel documents, tickets, leaflets and other miscellany from a trip i took to new zealand almost 4 years ago that made me realise it. i wonder is there some kind of 12 step programme for rehabilitation? step 1 - admit the truth. step 2 - revisit all hoardings (is that even a word?). step 3 - laugh (and sometimes cry) over the memories. step 4 - cough as a result of the dust disturbed. step 5 - procrastinate (perhaps by blogging). step 6 - sort half-heartedly. step 7 - procrastinate some more (it must be time for a refreshing beverage by now). step 8 - decide you really do need to keep that card/letter/receipt from 1992 (delete as appropriate). step 9 - sort again. step 10 - begin to actually (shock! horror!) get rid of some stuff. remember, it's always good to start slow. old cinema tickets hurt less than photographs. step 11 - take a fit of the head-staggers and get rid of everything you don't want/need/remember what it was/was used for. step 12 - put all that's left into a shoebox to save for the next time. result - hoarding problem is dealt with! i feel it may be time for a refreshing beverage...

And then, when we wanted it, the bottle could be uncorked, and it would be like living the moment all over again.” urlLink Rebecca , by Daphne du Maurier I never cease to be amazed by how much memory can be stored up in such small things. Turning over the pages of A-level notes, I am transported back into the classroom. Parquet floors, broken blinds, desks that rock unevenly when you lean on them. Discussions of poetry, diatribes about grammar, giggles regarding mispronunciations. Practice exam questions, essays, ‘compare and contrast’. Friendship. Study. Youth. Enthusiasm.
